original_title: Sri Lanka IOC-CPC joint venture to develop 9 tanks
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Indian Oil Corporation unit said nine tanks have been identified for development in the first phase of a joint venture with state-run Ceylon Petroleum Corporation.
The joint venture covers 61 tanks in the World War II era tank farm located near the North Western port of Trincomalee. LIOC already tanks in Trincomalee on a long term lease.

“The technical suitability has been completed and nine out of ten tanks were identified as suitable for the Phase 1 development stage,” Chairman Sujoy Choudhury told shareholders in the annual report.
“We have already commenced the ground clearing work around three tanks and envisage that a few tanks will be operational by the end of 2023.”
LIOC has also built a 3000 metric tonne capacity grease making plant.
LIOC also plans to open another 50 fuel station in 2023 taking their total network to 300 outlets.
Sri Lanka has further liberalized the petroleum distribution allowing more players to enter the sector, including China’s Sinopec and R M Parks-Shell. (Colombo/June19/2023)
